Greatest common divisor of a finite set

type:
{Œ± : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  {Œ≤ : Type u_2} ‚Üí [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero Œ±] ‚Üí [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid Œ±] ‚Üí Finset Œ≤ ‚Üí (Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ±) ‚Üí Œ±
name: Finset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a finite set

For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

type: ‚àÄ {n : ‚Ñï}, 1 ‚àà n.properDivisors ‚Üî 1 < n
name: Nat.one_mem_properDivisors_iff_one_lt
docString: For all natural numbers $n$, $1$ is a proper divisor of $n$ if and only if $n$ is a positive integer.

The theorem `Nat.gcd_pos_of_pos_left` states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `m` is greater than 0, then the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `m` and `n` is also greater than 0. In other words, if a natural number `m` is positive, its gcd with any other natural number `n` is also positive.

type: ‚àÄ {m : ‚Ñï} (n : ‚Ñï), 0 < m ‚Üí 0 < m.gcd n
name: Nat.gcd_pos_of_pos_left
docString: The theorem `Nat.gcd_pos_of_pos_left` states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, if `m` is greater than 0, then the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `m` and `n` is also greater than 0. In other words, if a natural number `m` is positive, its gcd with any other natural number `n` is also positive.

Division of `PosNum`,

type: PosNum ‚Üí PosNum ‚Üí Num
name: PosNum.div'
docString: Division of `PosNum`,

In the Cantor normal form representation of an ordinal number `o` with base `b`, every coefficient `x` has a positive second component.

type: ‚àÄ {b o : Ordinal.{u}} {x : Ordinal.{u} √ó Ordinal.{u}}, x ‚àà b.CNF o ‚Üí 0 < x.2
name: Ordinal.CNF_lt_snd
docString: In the Cantor normal form representation of an ordinal number `o` with base `b`, every coefficient `x` has a positive second component.

The theorem `Nat.pos_of_mem_divisors` states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `m`, if `m` is a member of the set of divisors of `n` (as defined by `Nat.divisors n`), then `m` is greater than zero. In other words, any divisor of a natural number, excluding zero itself, is always a positive natural number.

type: ‚àÄ {n m : ‚Ñï}, m ‚àà n.divisors ‚Üí 0 < m
name: Nat.pos_of_mem_divisors
docString: The theorem `Nat.pos_of_mem_divisors` states that for any two natural numbers `n` and `m`, if `m` is a member of the set of divisors of `n` (as defined by `Nat.divisors n`), then `m` is greater than zero. In other words, any divisor of a natural number, excluding zero itself, is always a positive natural number.

Alternative definition of set convexity, using division.

type:
